If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should like arts and subjects about people, while boys should do maths and physics. Also, young people often do not see women working in science jobs. In cartoons and stories, the crazy scientist, the smart inventor, or the brave astronaut is usually a man. Besides this, some people wrongly think scientists are nerdy, not good with others, or that their work is boring and separate from real life. These ideas come from TV, films, and books, but they are not true. Still, they can make girls feel that scientists are not like them, and that science is not a good job choice. If girls saw more women doing science and doing it well, they would feel more sure of themselves and feel they belong in science too.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. simplified: Don't always give negative feedback after positive feedback. If you do, people might start to ignore the good comments because they expect something negative to follow.
